title: 108_hr2807
content: The "Border Health Security Act of 2003" defines terms like "border area" and "Secretary" and establishes border health grants. The "Border Health Security Act of 2003" defines an eligible entity as a State, public institution of higher education, local government, tribal government, nonprofit health organization, or community health center in the border area. Grants are awarded to these entities to address health priorities and recommendations established by the United States-Mexico Border Health Commission, State border health offices, and the Secretary. Eligible entities can apply for grants from funds appropriated under the Act. An eligible entity seeking a grant under the Border Health Security Act of 2003 must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. Grant funds must be used for various health programs including maternal and child health, primary care, public health infrastructure, health promotion, oral health, mental health, substance abuse, and workforce training. The Border Health Security Act of 2003 provides grants for various health programs, including workforce training, community health workers, health care infrastructure, disparities, environmental health, education, and outreach services for Federal programs. Amounts awarded should supplement, not supplant, other funds available to the eligible entity. Authorization of Appropriations: $200,000,000 for fiscal year 2004, with additional funding as needed for future years, to support health programs under the Border Health Security Act of 2003. Border bioterrorism preparedness grants are authorized under the Border Health Security Act of 2003, with an appropriation of $200,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and additional funding for future years. The Border Health Security Act of 2003 authorizes grants for bioterrorism preparedness in the border area. Eligible entities include State, local, tribal, and public health entities. Grants are awarded by the Secretary from appropriated funds for developing and implementing bioterror preparedness plans, readiness assessments, and coordinating planning in the region. The Border Health Security Act of 2003 authorizes grants for bioterrorism preparedness in the border area. Eligible entities include State, local, tribal, and public health entities. Grants are awarded by the Secretary for improving infrastructure, creating a health alert network, educating and training personnel, and carrying out other activities identified by relevant authorities. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2004, with additional funding for succeeding years. The United States-Mexico Border Health Commission Act is amended to authorize appropriations of $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and ongoing years. The Secretary may coordinate with Homeland Security to establish a health alert system for detecting emerging disease clusters and bioterrorism threats along the border area.
